metadata.title: Effect of nano-TiO2 on the physical, mechanical and optical properties of pullulan film

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Carbohydrate Polymers
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/carbpol
Effect of nano-TiO2 on the physical, mechanical and optical properties of pullulan film
Yaofa Liua, Yuanyuan Liua, Ke Hana, Ying Caia, Meihu Maa, Qunyi Tongb, Long Shenga,⁎
aNational Research and Development Center for Egg Processing, College of Food Science and Technology, Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan, Hubei, 430070, China b The State Key Laboratory of Food Science and Technology, School of Food Science and Technology, Jiangnan University, Wuxi, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Polysaccharide film Nano-TiO2 Pullulan Nanocomposite
A B S T R A C T
In this study, effects of nano-TiO2 on the microstructural, physical, mechanical and optical properties of pullulan films were investigated. The results showed that the addition of nano-TiO2 improved the water vapor barrier properties of the film due to the tortuous path formed by nano-TiO2. When the concentration of nano-TiO2 was 0.04 g/100mL, the tensile strength of the film showed a maximum value (15.99MPa). The elongation at break of the film continued to decrease with the increase of nano-TiO2. The TEM analysis showed that higher concentration of nano-TiO2 would cause greater aggregation. Meanwhile, the results of FTIR and low-field NMR indicated that the miscibility between pullulan and nano-TiO2 was due to the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds during film formation. Furthermore, the addition of nano-TiO2 significantly improved the film barrier properties to ultraviolet light.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Petrochemical-based plastic packaging has caused more and more environmental problems, which makes people increasingly prefer to use biodegradable materials from natural polymers. Natural polymers including polysaccharides, lipids, proteins, and combinations, can be used as materials for the preparation of edible films (Gennadios, Weller, Hanna, & Froning, 2010). These edible films are environment friendly and can be used in food material packaging to extend shelf life and improve other qualities such as appearance, sensory attributes and freshness of ingredients (Hassan, Chatha, Hussain, Zia, & Akhtar, 2018). Recently, polysaccharides have been widely used as raw materials for edible films, which is attributed to many excellent properties of polysaccharide edible films, such as inhibiting or regulating the migration of moisture, carbon dioxide, oxygen, aromatic compounds, lipids, etc. (Zhu, Sheng, & Tong, 2014).
Pullulan, a water-soluble microbial exopolysaccharide produced by the fungus-like yeast, is a biodegradable, biocompatible, non-mutagenic, non-toxic, hygroscopic, non-carcinogenic and edible polymer (Sheng et al., 2017; Singh, Kaur, Rana, & Kennedy, 2017). This linear polymer consists mainly of maltotriose units linked to each other by a(1, 6) glycosidic bonds (Sheng et al., 2018; Singh, Saini, & Kennedy, 2008). Pullulan has impressive film-forming ability, such as colorless, tasteless, transparent, odorless, heat-sealable and impermeable to both
oxygen and oil (Farris, Unalan, Introzzi, Fuentes-Alventosa, & Cozzolino, 2014; Shih, Daigle, & Champagne, 2011; Tong, Xiao, & Lim, 2008; Wu, Zhong, Li, Shoemaker, & Xia, 2013).
In the past few decades, a large number of studies have been carried out on pullulan-based films (Hassannia-Kolaee, Khodaiyan, & ShahabiGhahfarrokhi, 2016; Horinaka, Hashimoto, & Takigawa, 2018; Kandemir et al., 2005; Xiao, Zhao, & Lim, 2017). However, pure pullulan films show some undesirable properties such as brittleness, hydrophilic nature, lack of active functions, etc. (Silva, Vilela, Almeida, Marrucho, & Freire, 2018; Mitsuhiro, Ryoichi, Naozumi, & Ryutoku, 2002; Yang, & Paulson, 2000). In order to overcome the shortcomings of pure pullulan films, pullulan-based composite and blends films are designed to obtain multifunctional packaging materials for improving the quality of the food. Currently, various functional agents have been applied to pullulan film, such as graphene oxide (Unalan et al., 2015), essential oils and nanoparticles (Morsy, Khalaf, Sharoba, Eltanahi, & Cutter, 2014), gelatin (Zhang, Gao, Ma, & Zhao, 2013), silver (Pinto et al., 2013), nanofibrillated cellulose (Trovatti et al., 2012), Sakacin A (Trinetta, Floros, & Cutter, 2010), thymol (Gniewosz & Synowiec, 2011), partially purified lysozyme (Kandemir et al., 2005) and colloidal silica nanoparticles (Cozzolino, Castelli, Trabattoni, & Farris, 2016).
Recently, nanomaterials have attracted considerable attention for enhancing the performance of biopolymer-based films (George & Siddaramaiah, 2012; Lupoi & Smith, 2011; Wang et al., 2014). Among
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbpol.2019.04.073 Received 27 December 2018; Received in revised form 18 April 2019; Accepted 23 April 2019
⁎ Corresponding author at: College of Food Science and Technology of Huazhong Agricultural University, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China. E-mail address: stheaven16@126.com (L. Sheng).
Carbohydrate Polymers 218 (2019) 95–102
Available online 27 April 2019 0144-8617/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
them, nano-TiO2 has been widely utilized because of its low price, nontoxicity, and light stability (Feng et al., 2007; Wang, Zhu, Li, Fu, & Shi, 2012). Nano-TiO2 is able to withstand the pressure during food processing and transportation when applied to food packaging (Arora & Padua, 2010). In addition, nano-TiO2 has a good UV blocking function. Nano-TiO2 can reduce the transmittance of light in UV-A, UV-B and visible light regions, which plays an important role in preventing photoinduced oxidative deterioration in food packaging systems (Li et al., 2011). Meantime, due to the excellent photocatalytical activity of anatase nano-TiO2, when the film containing anatase nano-TiO2 is exposed to UV light, the generated hydroxyl group disrupts the covalent bond in the peptidoglycan layer, thereby disrupting cell wall stability in Gram-positive bacteria (GR+) and Gram-negative bacteria (GR−) (Ge et al., 2015). However, there is currently no published study about the effect of nano-TiO2 on the properties of pullulan film.
Therefore, in this research, the nano-TiO2-pullulan composite films were successfully prepared by solution casting method. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the influence of nano-TiO2 on the physical, mechanical and optical properties of pullulan film. Furthermore, the differences in structure between the nano-TiO2-pullulan composite film and pure pullulan film were characterized.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Pullulan (molecular weight 200,000 Da) was provided from the Hayashibara Biochemical Laboratories (Okayama, Japan), and NMR results (Fig. 1S) confirmed that it consists mainly of maltotriose units linked to each other by a-(1, 6) glycosidic bonds, and HPLC results (Table 1S) showed the glucose content of pullulan's monosaccharide composition was 99.33%. TiO2 nanoparticles (Anatase phase, particle size 5–10 nm) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All other chemicals (analytical grade) used were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: 2.2. Film preparation
sections.text: To obtain different concentrations of nano-TiO2 solution, different amounts of nano-TiO2 powder were added to distilled water (100mL), magnetically stirred for 30min and treated by ultrasound for 30min. And then these different concentrations of nano-TiO2 solutions were separately poured into beakers containing pullulan power (4 g) and glycerin (0.6 g), magnetically stirred at room temperature until completely dissolved to obtain film solutions. Film solution (25mL) was uniformly spread on a clean and dry petri dish (8.5 cm in diameter) and dried in an oven at 40 °C for 48 h. Dried films were peeled after cooling and stored in desiccator at 53% relative humidity (containing saturated magnesium nitrate solution) at 25 °C for at least 72 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. Mechanical properties
sections.text:
According to ASTM standard method D882-02 (ASTM, 2002), Texture Analyzer (TA-XT2i) was used to determine the tensile strength (TS, MPa) and elongation at break (E, %) of the film. The films were cut into rectangular strips (2 cm×8 cm), and the initial grip separation was set at 60mm and crosshead speed at 1mm/s. The results were the average of eight samples. TS was calculated by dividing the maximum load by the cross-sectional area of the specimen, elongation at break (E, %) was calculated by the following equation:
= − ×E L L L % 100%max 0 0
Where L0 is the initial length of the film, Lmax is the length of the film when it breaks.

sections.heading: 2.4. Water vapor permeability
sections.text: The water vapor permeability (WVP) was determined according to modified ASTM E96 (ASTM, 1993) described by Zhu et al. (2014). After 72 h of equilibrium at 53% RH, films were sealed on the top of cups containing distilled water (3160 Pa vapor pressure at 25 °C, 100% RH), which were placed in a cabinet containing silica gel at 25 °C (0 Pa vapor pressure, 0% RH). Then the test cups were weighed every 2 h for 24 h. The weight of water passing through the film was determined according to the reduction in the weight of the test cups.

sections.heading: 2.5. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis
sections.text: The XRD data were obtained using an X-ray diffractometer (D8 Advance, Bruker AXS, Karlsruhe, Germany) in the 2θ range 2–40° at 2°/ min. Before testing, the test films were stored in a desiccator containing silica gel (0% RH). The test conditions were set as 36 kV, 30mA, one degree scattering slit, one degree divergence slit, and 0.3mm receiving slit.

sections.heading: 2.6. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA)
sections.text: Thermal stability of films were analyzed using a thermogravimetric analyzer, ShimadzuTGA-50 (Shimadzu Corporation, Kyoto, Japan). Samples were placed under a controlled atmosphere and heated from 30 °C to 400 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

sections.heading: 2.7. Apparent surface color measurement
sections.text: Film color was determined by using an automatic color chroma meter (CR-400/410, Konica Minolta Sensing Inc., Tokyo, Japan). Each sample was measured 8 times. Color parameters (L*, a* and b*) were determined from the average value of eight readings.

sections.heading: 2.8. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
sections.text: The surfaces of the blend films were characterized by using a scanning electron microscope (Model S-4800 SEM, Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The fractured films were mounted on mental stubs by a doublesided adhesive tape and then sputtered coated with gold. Samples were observed with an operating voltage of 10.0 kV.

sections.heading: 2.9. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM)
sections.text: The TEM images of the pure nano-TiO2 and pullulan based films were measured by H-7650 (Hitachi Co. Ltd., Japan). The acceleration voltage employed was 100 KV. The nano-TiO2 solution was prepared by adding ethanol to the nano-TiO2. The samples were prepared by adding a drop of film-forming solution or the nano-TiO2 solution onto a carboncoated copper grid.

sections.heading: 2.10. Spectrophotometric analysis
sections.text: The ultraviolet (UV) and visible light transmittances through the film sample were measured by a UV / Vis spectrophotometer (NANO 2000C, Thermo, USA) at 190 nm, 300 nm, 360 nm, and 600 nm, respectively. All film samples were cut into rectangles and attached to the inner wall of a quartz cuvette for spectral measurements.

sections.heading: 2.11. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of the films were measured using a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet Nexus 470, Thermo Electron, USA) equipped with a germanium crystal ATR accessory. Spectra were acquired in Attenuated Total Refectance mode from 750 to 4000 cm−1 with 2 cm−1 resolution. Each spectrum resulted from an average of 64 scans.
2.12. Low field nuclear magnetic resonance (LF-NMR) measurements
A NMI-20-Analyst NMR analyzer (Niumag Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China) was used to attain useful information about water in the film samples at the molecular level. The transverse relaxation (T2) curve was measured by Carr-Purcell-Meiboom-Gill (CPMG) pulse sequence at 32 °C. The film samples were placed in NMR test tube (15mm in diameter). The test parameters were as follow: recycle time= 2000ms, echo count= 8000, scan repetitions= 16, echo time=0.17ms. The NMR data analyzed by an inversion to the T2 sprctrum.

sections.heading: 2.13. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements
sections.text: 20mg pullulan sample were dissolved in 1mL D2O. Using tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard, 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded by a Bruker Avance III (600MHz) spectrometer.

sections.heading: 2.14. Monosaccharide analysis
sections.text: PMP derivatization procedure was performed as described previously (Wang, Zhao, Pu, & Luan, 2016). The Agilent 1200 HPLC system was used for monosaccharide analysis with SHISEIDO C18 column (4.6 mm×250mm, 5 μm). Using a 0.1mol/L phosphate buffer (pH 6.9) and acetonitrile in a ratio of 82:18 (v, %) as a mobile phase, a chromatographic separation of PMP derivatives was carried out at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min. The temperature of the column was maintained at 25 °C and detected at 245 nm.

sections.heading: 2.15. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Experimental data were reported as means ± standard deviation for multiple replications. The difference between means was considered significant at P < 0.05 (Duncan’s new multiple range test). All data were statistically analyzed using SPSS software (version 12.0 for Windows; SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).

sections.heading: 3.1. Water vapor permeability
sections.text: WVP is one of the most crucial properties of films for application in food storage (Sungae, Geumok, & Song, 2010). The WVP values for blended and pure films are shown in Fig. 1. The WVP value of pullulan film was 7.9× 10−4 gm/m2 h KPa, which was in accordance with other previous study (Wu et al., 2013). The addition of nano-TiO2 enhanced the water vapor barrier properties of pullulan film. With the increase of nano-TiO2, the WVP value of the blend film gradually decreased until the minimum WVP value (6.6× 10−4 gm/m2 h KPa) was obtained with 0.04 g nano-TiO2 addition, and then increased. Because nano-TiO2 has higher water resistance than the pullulan matrix, the nano-TiO2 dispersed in the pullulan matrix created a tortuous pathway where water vapor passed, thus increasing the time of water vapor molecules passing through the pullulan matrix (Wang et al., 2014). In the study of Hyeock, Yeon, and Jin (2018), the halloysite nanotubes with higher water resistance was incorporated into chitosan films, and similar results were observed in the WVP of films. Therefore, low concentration of nano-TiO2 particles could properly dispersed in the pullulan matrix to block the water vapor. However, when the concentration of nano-TiO2 was high, the excessive nano-TiO2 particles would be aggregated due to its high surface energy. This aggregation resulted in the decrease of the effective content of the nano-TiO2 particles and destruction of the pullulan matrix, which may hinder the formation of tortuous paths. The following SEM and TEM analysis also proved this aggregation.

sections.heading: 3.2. Mechanical properties
sections.text: Mechanical properties are significant parameters to evaluate the stress tolerance of food packaging materials in handling, transportation and storage (Ge et al., 2018). Tensile strength (TS) accounts for film strength, while elongation at break (EAB) measures the extension ability of a film before breaking. Generally, films with high TS display low EAB (Vachon et al., 2000). As shown in Fig. 1, the TS of the films with nano-TiO2 was greater than that without nano-TiO2, while the trend of EAB presented the opposite tendency. This phenomenon indicated that the addition of nano-TiO2 enhanced the cohesion force of the films and reduced the flexibility of the films. Nano-TiO2 improved the stiffness, thereby increasing TS. Excessive concentration of nanoTiO2 might accumulate and destroy the pullulan matrix, which was also found in WVP analysis, leading to a decrease in TS. On the one hand, TS first increased and then decreased with the concentration of nano-TiO2 increased, and the film with 0.04 g nano-TiO2 had the maximum TS (15.99MPa). This result was consistent with the trend of film’s WVP. On the other hand, EAB continuously decreased as the nano-TiO2 concentration increased. In the study of Vejdan, Ojagh, Adeli, and Abdollahi (2016), as the amount of nano-TiO2 incorporated into the fish gelatin/agar bilayer increased, TS increased first and then decreased, while EAB continued to decrease. The trends of TS and EAB were in accord with this study.

sections.heading: 3.3. XRD analysis
sections.text: XRD data of the films and the pure TiO2 are shown in Fig. 2. The characteristic peaks exhibited by the nano-TiO2 particles at 2θ of 26°- 75° indicated that they were pure nano-TiO2 (Kaplan, Erjavec, Dražić, Grdadolnik, & Pintar, 2016). The pure pullulan film showed a characteristic peak at 2θ of 21°, indicating that pullulan showed a noncrystalline structure, which was in agreement with other previous study (Wu et al., 2013). After the addition of nano-TiO2, the peak intensity of the diffraction peak at 2θ of 21° was significantly stronger, which may be caused by the interaction between nano-TiO2 and pullulan. When the concentration of nano-TiO2 was low (0.02 g/100mL), the crystal structure of nano-TiO2 was almost undetectable. With the increase of nano-TiO2, the new diffraction peak appeared at 2θ of 26° and the peak intensity increased, indicating that the crystallinity of high-concentration nano-TiO2 might be gradually restore. The high concentration of nano-TiO2 itself aggregated, which verified the WVP and mechanical properties analysis of the film.

sections.heading: 3.4. Thermogravimetric analysis
sections.text: The thermal stability of the film was investigated using a TGA in the range of 30–400 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. It can be seen from Fig. 3, the pure pullulan film produced two thermal degradation. The temperature range for the first step of thermal degradation was 100–270 °C, which was attributed to the evaporation of water in the films. The temperature range for the second step of thermal degradation was 270–330 °C which was attributed to the loss of plasticizer glycerin in the films and the production of a carbonaceous residue. Zhu et al. (2014) also found that the pure pullulan film underwent a very similar two-step thermal degradation. After the addition of nano-TiO2, the TGA results of the films did not change significantly, indicating that nanoTiO2 did not affect the thermal stability of the pullulan film in this study. Similar results have been reported in other studies. For cast zein protein with and without nano-TiO2 (Kadam et al., 2017), soy protein isolate and montmorillonite composite film (Kumar, Sandeep, Alavi, Truong, & Gorga, 2010), the similar two-step thermal degradation was also reported.

sections.heading: 3.5. Film surface color and images
sections.text:
The macroscopic appearance of pure pullulan film and complex pullulan film containing different concentrations of nano-TiO2 are
presented using digitally photograph (Fig. 4). As can be seen, all of the films exhibited a homogenous smooth and flat surface. As the concentration of nano-TiO2 increased, the transparency of the film gradually decreased, which was also observed in the spectrophotometric analysis of film.
In addition, the color properties of the films are of utmost importance because they directly affect consumer acceptability of the products (Sabina, 2018). The color difference among the films was evaluated by measuring the L*, a* and b* value. The test results of all the films are shown in Table 1. As the nano-TiO2 increased, the lightness (L*) value increased from 93.35 to 95.72, and the green-red (a)
Mean± standard deviation values (n= 8) in the same column denoted with different superscripts are significantly different (P < 0.05).
value decreased from 4.74 to 3.98, and the addition of nano-TiO2 made the film whiter, which may be related to the white color of the nanoTiO2 itself (Vejdan et al., 2016). Blue-yellow (b*) value increased from −1.73 to 1.61, indicating that nano-TiO2 tended to change the color of the film from light blue to pale yellow.

sections.heading: 3.6. SEM and TEM analysis
sections.text:
The surface microstructure of all films is shown in Fig. 5(a–e). It could be seen that all the films presented a smooth and homogenous surface without cracks and holes. Similar results were reported for pullulan films with lysozyme nanofibers (Silva et al., 2018) and pullulan-whey protein bionanocomposite films cotaining nanoclay (Hassannia-Kolaee et al., 2016), that displayed a homogenous and smooth surface. For fish gelatin/agar bilayer film containing nano-TiO2 (Vejdan et al., 2016) which presented homogenous surface microstructures.
The TEM image of nano-TiO2 aggregation is shown in Fig. 5f for comparison with nano-TiO2 in film samples. Meantime, The TEM images of films are shown in Fig. 5(g–j). As the nano-TiO2 increased, it could be observed that nano-TiO2 aggregates similar to those of Fig. 5f appeared, and the aggregates gradually increased. These results corresponded well with the results of WVP and mechanical properties. Similar results also appeared on the TEM images of the nanosilica-chitosan blend films (Liu, Cai, Sheng, Ma, & Xu, 2019).
3.7. Optical properties of the films
Transmittance values for all sample films at 190 nm (UV-C), 300 nm (UV-B), 360 nm (UV-A) and 600 nm (visible light) are shown in Table 2. The addition of nano-TiO2 significantly reduced the transmittance values of pullulan films at all measured wavelengths. Moreover, as the nano-TiO2 increased, the transmittance values of all sample films at all measured wavelengths decreased. At the same time, it could be observed that in the process of increasing the concentration of nano-TiO2 from 0 g/100mL to 0.06 g/100mL, the transmittance values of all the sample films at all measurement wavelengths reduced to a greater extent. However, as the concentration of nano-TiO2 continued to increase, the decrease of the transmittance value became unapparent. Among properties of food packaging, UV barrier is a key performance to ensure food quality, because ultraviolet light can cause a series of negative effects such as loss of nutrients in food, lipid oxidation, etc., resulting in degradation of packaging food and quality (Hyeock et al., 2018). The experimental results showed that the addition of nano-TiO2 significantly improved the barrier property of the pullulan film to ultraviolet light.

sections.heading: 3.8. FTIR analysis
sections.text:
FTIR spectroscopy was used to detect the interaction between pullulan and nano-TiO2. Fig. 6 shows FTIR spectra of blended and pure films. For pure pullulan film, a broad peak around 3280 cm−1 was assigned to OeH stretching which was affected by the intra-molecular or
inter-molecular hydrogen bonds. The peak around 2930 cm−1 was assigned to the C–H stretching, while the peak around 1350 cm−1 corresponded to the C–O stretching vibration. In addition, the peak located around 1150 cm−1 may be the polysaccharide (1–4) glycosidic bond stretching vibration. These main characteristic absorption bands of pure pullulan were in agreement with previous reports (Sheng et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2013).
The chemical interaction between pullulan and nano-TiO2 could be observed by the transition of the peak position of the main group. In the spectrum of these pullulan and nano-TiO2 blend films, the shift of one peak was observed: from 3280 cm−1 (0 g/100mL TiO2) to 3305 cm−1 (0.08 g/100mL TiO2). Meanwhile, with the increase of nano-TiO2, hydroxyl peak shifted toward longer wavenumber, which was most likely related to the hydrogen bond formed by the interaction of pullulan with nano-TiO2. However, no significant shift was observed for other characteristic peaks of pullulan, such as peaks at 2930 cm-1 (C–H stretching), 1350 cm-1 (C–O stretching), and 1150 cm-1 (polysaccharide (1–4) glycosidic bond stretching), indicating that nano-TiO2 did not alter these structures of pullulan.
3.9. Low field nuclear magnetic resonance (LF-NMR) analysis
Fig.7 shows the T2 spectrum of pullulan films with and without nano-TiO2. It could be observed that each film sample had three peaks (T21, T22 and T23) in the T2 spectrum. The onset time and peak area ratio of each peak are shown in the Table 3. For the peak T21, the peak could be attributed to the tightly bound water molecules, which directly interacted with the −OH group of pullulan in the entanglement zone of the pullulan chains (Xiao, Lim, Zhou, & Zhao, 2017). At the same time, the peak T22 and T23 were assigned to moderately bound water and loosely bound water in the network (Liu et al., 2019).
The change in the proportion of peak area can also reflect the change in the water content. For the peak T21, it could be seen that the proportion of peak area increased when the concentration of the nanoTiO2 increased from 0 g/100mL to 0.02 g/100mL, which might be attributed to the fact that the addition of the nano-TiO2 caused the polymer to expose more hydrogen bonds. With the further increase of the concentration of nano-TiO2, the proportion of peak T21 area gradually decreased. This phenomenon demonstrated that nano-TiO2 combined with the hydroxyl group in the polymer, and the content of water molecules originally combined with the polymer hydroxyl group reduced. In the meantime, moderately bound water and loosely bound water were formed, which were corresponding to peak T22 and T23. The combination of nano-TiO2 and hydroxyl groups in pullulan polymers had also been verified in FTIR studies. Consequently, it could be concluded that the miscibility between pullulan and nano-TiO2 resulted from the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds during film formation, and the stable hydrogen bonds were formed between O in nano-TiO2 and H in C–OeH of pullulan. In the study of Xiong, Sheng, Wang, & Guo, (2019), the similar stable hydrogen bonds were formed between water-resistant starch and nano-TiO2.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, different concentrations of nano-TiO2 were added to improve some properties of the pullulan film. Pullulan film containing 0.04 g/100mL of nano-TiO2 had the most excellent water vapor barrier (WVP value is 6.6× 10−4 gm/m2 h KPa) and tensile strength (15.99MPa). At the same time, the effect of the addition of nano-TiO2 on the thermal stability of the pullulan film was not significant. In addition, in the XRD analysis, we found that excessive nano-TiO2 would aggregate and destroyed the pullulan matrix. Meanwhile, the aggregation phenomenon of high concentration nano-TiO2 could also be visually observed on the TEM images of the film samples. Therefore, the results indicated that the lower concentration of nano-TiO2 had a positive effect on the improvement of water vapor barrier properties,
mechanical properties and UV barrier properties of the pullulan film. In addition, the hydrogen bond formed between nano-TiO2 and pullulan was the basis of the miscibility of the composite film. Nano-TiO2Pullulan blend films may have potential as food packaging, but further research in real food systems is needed.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 31701622), Hubei Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 2018CFB606), and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (Program No. 2662018JC022).

sections.text: Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbpol.2019.04.073.

referenceMentions.context: Pullulan, a water-soluble microbial exopolysaccharide produced by the fungus-like yeast, is a biodegradable, biocompatible, non-mutagenic, non-toxic, hygroscopic, non-carcinogenic and edible polymer (Sheng et al., 2017; Singh, Kaur, Rana, & Kennedy, 2017).
This linear polymer consists mainly of maltotriose units linked to each other by a(1, 6) glycosidic bonds (Sheng et al., 2018; Singh, Saini, & Kennedy, 2008).

In the past few decades, a large number of studies have been carried out on pullulan-based films (Hassannia-Kolaee, Khodaiyan, & ShahabiGhahfarrokhi, 2016; Horinaka, Hashimoto, & Takigawa, 2018; Kandemir et al., 2005; Xiao, Zhao, & Lim, 2017).
Currently, various functional agents have been applied to pullulan film, such as graphene oxide (Unalan et al., 2015), essential oils and nanoparticles (Morsy, Khalaf, Sharoba, Eltanahi, &
Cutter, 2014), gelatin (Zhang, Gao, Ma, & Zhao, 2013), silver (Pinto et al., 2013), nanofibrillated cellulose (Trovatti et al.
, 2013), nanofibrillated cellulose (Trovatti et al., 2012), Sakacin A (Trinetta, Floros, & Cutter, 2010), thymol (Gniewosz & Synowiec, 2011), partially purified lysozyme (Kandemir et al.

, 2012), Sakacin A (Trinetta, Floros, & Cutter, 2010), thymol (Gniewosz & Synowiec, 2011), partially purified lysozyme (Kandemir et al., 2005) and colloidal silica nanoparticles (Cozzolino, Castelli, Trabattoni, & Farris, 2016).
them, nano-TiO2 has been widely utilized because of its low price, nontoxicity, and light stability (Feng et al., 2007; Wang, Zhu, Li, Fu, & Shi, 2012).

Nano-TiO2 can reduce the transmittance of light in UV-A, UV-B and visible light regions, which plays an important role in preventing photoinduced oxidative deterioration in food packaging systems (Li et al., 2011).

Meantime, due to the excellent photocatalytical activity of anatase nano-TiO2, when the film containing anatase nano-TiO2 is exposed to UV light, the generated hydroxyl group disrupts the covalent bond in the peptidoglycan layer, thereby disrupting cell wall stability in Gram-positive bacteria (GR) and Gram-negative bacteria (GR) (Ge et al., 2015).
According to ASTM standard method D882-02 (ASTM, 2002), Texture Analyzer (TA-XT2i) was used to determine the tensile strength (TS, MPa) and elongation at break (E, %) of the film.
The water vapor permeability (WVP) was determined according to modified ASTM E96 (ASTM, 1993) described by Zhu et al.
9× 10 gm/m(2) h KPa, which was in accordance with other previous study (Wu et al., 2013).

Because nano-TiO2 has higher water resistance than the pullulan matrix, the nano-TiO2 dispersed in the pullulan matrix created a tortuous pathway where water vapor passed, thus increasing the time of water vapor molecules passing through the pullulan matrix (Wang et al., 2014).
Mechanical properties are significant parameters to evaluate the stress tolerance of food packaging materials in handling, transportation and storage (Ge et al., 2018).
Generally, films with high TS display low EAB (Vachon et al., 2000).
The pure pullulan film showed a characteristic peak at 2θ of 21°, indicating that pullulan showed a noncrystalline structure, which was in agreement with other previous study (Wu et al., 2013).

For cast zein protein with and without nano-TiO2 (Kadam et al., 2017), soy protein isolate and montmorillonite composite film (Kumar, Sandeep, Alavi, Truong, & Gorga, 2010), the similar two-step thermal degradation was also reported.
portance because they directly affect consumer acceptability of the products (Sabina, 2018).

Similar results were reported for pullulan films with lysozyme nanofibers (Silva et al., 2018) and pullulan-whey protein bionanocomposite films cotaining nanoclay (Hassannia-Kolaee et al.
, 2018) and pullulan-whey protein bionanocomposite films cotaining nanoclay (Hassannia-Kolaee et al., 2016), that displayed a homogenous and smooth surface.
For fish gelatin/agar bilayer film containing nano-TiO2 (Vejdan et al., 2016) which presented homogenous surface microstructures.

These main characteristic absorption bands of pure pullulan were in agreement with previous reports (Sheng et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2013).

At the same time, the peak T22 and T23 were assigned to moderately bound water and loosely bound water in the network (Liu et al., 2019).

metadata.abstractText: In this study, effects of nano-TiO2 on the microstructural, physical, mechanical and optical properties of pullulan films were investigated. The results showed that the addition of nano-TiO2 improved the water vapor barrier properties of the film due to the tortuous path formed by nano-TiO2. When the concentration of nano-TiO2 was 0.04 g/100mL, the tensile strength of the film showed a maximum value (15.99MPa). The elongation at break of the film continued to decrease with the increase of nano-TiO2. The TEM analysis showed that higher concentration of nano-TiO2 would cause greater aggregation. Meanwhile, the results of FTIR and low-field NMR indicated that the miscibility between pullulan and nano-TiO2 was due to the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds during film formation. Furthermore, the addition of nano-TiO2 significantly improved the film barrier properties to ultraviolet light.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
